description.narrative: This project supports functionality of rule of law institutions and youth participation in peace building activities while promoting durable solutions for Internally displaced Persons (IDPs) and returnees in Golo, Jabel Marra.

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Outcome Indicator 1 a: Percentage of community members reporting a decrease in communal conflicts including child rights and GBV violations. Outcome Indicator 1 b: Percentage of community members reporting satisfaction with informal and formal rule of law mechanisms initiatives. Outcome Indicator 1 c: Number of young people/adolescents with peacebuilding competencies and meaningful engagement at community level Output Indicator 1.1.1: % of populations who state increase in access to PJRCs and para-legal services. Output Indicator 1.1.2: Number of para-legals trained (disaggregated by gender and age) Output Indicator 1.1.3: Number of cases successfully mediated Output Indicator 1.2.1: Number of community-based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning and composition (disaggregated by gender and age) Output Indicator 1.2.2: % cases successfully mediated and resolved by CBRMs. Output Indicator 1.2.3: Percentage of community members stating a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRM Output Indicator 1.3.1: Number of human rights issues identified and being addressed Output Indicator 1.3.2: Number of community members attending awareness campaigns on human rights, access to justice and legal aid (disaggregated by gender and age) Output Indicator 1.4.1: Number of community policing volunteers (CPVs) identified, trained and membership (disaggregated by gender and age) Output Indicator 1.4.2: Number of community members (community policing volunteers) from different villages/tribes participating in post conflict, multi-tribal exchange trainings including nomads (disaggregated by gender and age Output Indicator 1.4.3: % of female Police Officers trained in SGBV Output Indicator 1.4.4: Number of Rural Courts established Outcome Indicator 2 a: Number of returnee households in target villages and IDP households reintegrated and receiving basic social services because of project interventions Outcome Indicator 2 b: Number of women and men benefitting fro

comment.narrative: While Internally displaced Persons (IDPs) have started to return to Golo, socio-economic conditions in Golo needs further improvements.

1.1 60% of population who state increase in access to PJRCs and para-legal services. 1.2 30 Paralegal trained (disaggregated by gender and age). 1.3 100 cases successfully mediated. 1.4 10 community based resolution mechanisms (CBRM) functioning and composition (disaggregated by gender and age) 1.5 80% cases successfully mediated and resolved by CBRMs. 1.6 80% members stating a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRM. 1.7 2 human rights issues identified and being addressed. 1.8 200 community members attending awareness campaigns on human rights, access to justice and legal aid (disaggregated by gender and age). 1.9 10 community policing volunteers (CPVs) identified, trained and membership (disaggregated by gender and age). 1.10 50 Community policing volunteers from different villages/tribes participating in post conflict, multi-tribal exchange trainings including nomads (disaggregated by gender and age). 1.11 40% Female police officers trained in SGBV 1.12 1 Rural Courts established

1.1 50% of the population reported an increase in access to PJRC and paralegal services 1.2 0 Paralegal trained (disaggregated by gender and age). Will be achieved in 2020 1.3 144 cases successfully mediated. 1.4 114 CBRMs established with 175 members (33% women & 45% Youth) from Fur, Zagawa, Masalit & Arab tribes. 1.5 100% cases successfully mediated and resolved by CBRMs where 144 cases were received and all were mediated and resolved to the satisfaction of both parties 1.6 86% members stating a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRM. 1.7 0 human rights issues identified and being addressed. To be achieved in 2020 1.8 1,500 community members attending awareness campaigns on human rights, access to justice and legal aid (40% women and 55% Youth). 1.9 0 community policing volunteers (CPVs) identified, trained and membership (disaggregated by gender and age). This will be achieved in December 1.10 0 Community policing volunteers from different villages/tribes participating in post conflict, multi-tribal exchange trainings including nomads (disaggregated by gender and age). Under discussion with UNAMID 1.11 0 Female police officers trained in SGBV to be completed in December 2019 1.12 1 Rural Court established
1.1 80% cases 1.2 2 human rights issues 1.3 30 paralegals 1.4 50 CPVs 1.5 40% Female police officers 2.1 20% net income 2.2 2 cold storage facilities 2.3 10 farmers trained 2.4 20 graduates

86% of community members reported a decrease in communal conflicts including child rights and GBV violations 93% of community members satisfied with informal and 83% formal rule of law mechanisms initiatives 117 youth (31 percent female) gained peacebuilding competencies and meaningful engagement at community level 50 % of populations state increase in access to PJRCs and para-legal services 12 paralegals (17 percent women; 33 percent youth) trained (disaggregated by gender and age) 144 cases successfully mediated 14 CBRMs established with 131 members (33 percent women and 45 percent Youth) 100% cases successfully mediated and resolved by CBRMs 86% of community members stated a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRM 5 human rights issues identified and being addressed 300 community members attended awareness campaigns on human rights, access to justice and legal aid 33 CPVs (all male) community policing volunteers (CPVs) identified, trained 50 community members (community policing volunteers) from different villages/tribes participated in post conflict, multi-tribal exchange trainings including nomads 0% female Police Officers trained in SGBV. The project attempted to engage women to train as female police officers but failed due to cultural and religious beliefs within Golo communities 1 Rural Court established 5,000 returnee households in target villages and IDP households reintegrated and receiving basic social services because of project interventions 15,450 community members (65 percent women, 35 percent youth) women and men benefitting from economic recovery opportunities within eighteen months of intervention, disaggregated by vulnerability groups, gender and age 81% of community members reporting an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities 97% of target groups reporting increased trust between members of community and their local authorities Eighty (80) youths (38 percent females) Youth trained as volunteers from different tribes including nomads and deployed 113 (28% female) youths trained at Youth Centre in diversified vocational skills 13 peacebuilding activities implemented by Youth Volunteers 9 value chain related producer groups / cooperatives established / reactivated and 60 percent women participating 9 producer association/cooperatives established and functional 88% of people in target areas with improved perceptions of social cohesion within eighteen months of project implementation due to the concept of collective work 35% increase of net annual income achieved by producer groups and households attributable to project activities 7 water harvesting facilities constructed / rehabilitated 2,400 community members (45 percent women, 50 percent youth) employed in temporary labour intensive schemes 25km community ‘access to markets” roads established/rehabilitated and distance covered under CFW 1 storage facilities with cooling systems installed 10 farmers association members (30% female) trained on operation and maintenance of the refrigerated storage facilities 22 youth Centre graduates from different villages/tribes involved in packaging materials manufacturing (disaggregated by gender and age) 1 water resources rehabilitated / constructed along the migratory routes 2 Animal Health Centers established and stocked 15,000 animals treated and vaccinated 20 CAHWs (10 percent female, 26 percent youth) trained and equipped
N/A. The project has no planned activities in 2021.
